bibl.title: Report on the control of malarial mosquitoes, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]

div1.p: [Carter] proposes that the International Health Commission carry out an experiment involving the control of malarial mosquitoes. He includes a detailed procedure for such an experiment.

div1.head: Report on the control of malarial mosquitoes, by [Henry Rose Carter], [19--]
div1.p:
In view of the foregoing exhibit of facts, it
is proposed that the International Health Commission
undertake to carry out an experiment which it is
hoped may become a demonstration in the control of
malaria. The purpose of the undertaking will be to
try out on a small scale selected combinations of
control measures in order to determine what degree
of malaria control may be accomplished under the con-
ditions of the average rural community in the
Southern states; to determine the most effective
methods of operation; and to standardize the working
unit of organization and the cost. For this demon-
stration the following tentative plan of procedure
is proposed:

1. Select a small rural community in area about
36 square miles; one in which malaria is very prevalent
and has been prevalent for a long time; a community
free from hookworm disease to avoid this complicating
factor; a community as much isolated as possible to
prevent the introduction of infection from the outside;
a community which offers hearty cooperation on the part
of the people and of the local physicians.

2. Make a map of the community showing location
of streams, roads and farm homes.

3. Take a census of the population, recording
by families name, age, sex, color, address.

4. Make a survey to determine prevalence of
malaria and its effects; the findings to include:
(1) The parasite rate based on blood examination.)
(2) The spleen rate based on spleen examination.)
3) Average haemoglobin index of the community
based on blood examination.
4) Days lost from work and from school, based
on individual history.
5) History as to chills, fever and malaria.
Report of local physicians to be used
in connection with history of cases.
5. Exhibit results of survey on map.

6. Instruct the people of the community by
illustrated lectures; by leaflets; by exhibits; by
course in the schools; by house to house canvass. This
instruction to be definite; to be simple; to be directed
to the measure or measures to be carried out; to cover
what is expected of each individual, of each family,
of the community as a whole; to be driven home by such
insistent repetition and energy as may be required to
secure the desired action.
7. Carry out the selected control measures:

1) In at least one such test community all
effort will be centered on the single measure of
treating all malaria carriers with quinine. The
purpose here will be to determine to what degree malaria
may be controlled in our temperate climate by destroy-
ing the parasites in the blood of the human host. This
treatment to be carried out on the basis of from 20 to
30 grains of quinine a day for two or three days a
week for six weeks; results to be tested by repeated
blood examinations; to be continued till cure is
effected.

2) In at least one other community the
treatment of carriers will be supplemented:

a. By mosquito reduction: killing mature
mosquitoes in the house; destroying breeding places
by removing, emptying or screening artificial con-
tainers about the house; filling or draining puddles,
pools, ponds, urging only such measures as are
feasible for the family or community in question.

b. By protecting the individual from the
bites of the mosquito by means of screening; clearing
weeds and brush from about the house; using mosquito
bars and avoiding needless exposure from sunset to
4.
sunrise. In all cases placing the emphasis on those
measures which are feasible under the conditions of
the given case.

8. On completion of the work make a re-survey
to get the measure of results. Formulate the work
and its results in most impressive form and publish
to the community.

If the undertaking should be successful and
the experiment should thus become a demonstration,
the work could be extended at will in the Southern
states and in foreign countries. Its extension
would be primarily a matter of education and could
be carried out:

1. By making a series of demonstrations in
selected communities throughout infected regions.

2. By publishing and distributing the story
of these demonstrations, enlisting the press.

3. By teaching the people living in infected
regions by means of illustrated lectures and exhibits.

4. By teaching physicians the importance of
curing carriers and teaching them how to do it.

5. By supplying leaflets and charts for definite
instruction in the public schools and enlisting the
school children in the active work of mosquito
reduction.
